data.title: C/C++ plugin, includePaths should not search recursively
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: OS/X 10.11.2

#492 was landed, which helps a little with #374 but still doesn't solve our problem completely.

Let's say I have a directory structure like this:

```
mbed-os
    - mbed.h
    - folder1
        - rtos.h
    - folder2
        - unrelated-file.h
```

I create my ``c_cpp_properties.json`` like this:

```
        {
            "includePath": [
                "${workspaceRoot}/mbed-os",
                "${workspaceRoot}/mbed-os/folder1"
            ],
            "name": "Mac",
            "browse": {
                "databaseFilename": "",
                "limitSymbolsToIncludedHeaders": false
            }
        }
```

However, the includePaths are searched through recursively and thus `folder2` is still added to intellisense.

We need a setting to not search through includePaths recursively.

Related #475.

/cc @sg-

data.title: Save All should save existing files even when an unsaved file is currently open

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

**Feature request**

- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: Windows 10 Home 1607

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open an existing file
2. Make a change to said file
3. Create a new file (CTRL+N)
4. Make a change to the newly created file
5. Save all (CTRL+K S by default)

Expected behavior: the changes to the previously existing file are saved, and a 'Save As' dialog opens asking where to save the newly created file.

Actual behavior: as above, but the changes to the previously existing file are **not** saved.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.10.2 (8076a19fdcab7e1fc1707952d652f0bb6c6db331, 2017-03-08T14:02:52.799Z)

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|html-snippets|abusaidm|0.1.0|
|EditorConfig|EditorConfig|0.6.0|
|autoimport|steoates|1.2.2|
|Angular2|UVBrain|0.4.1|;


---

Steps to Reproduce:

I made a gif to illustrate:

![hi](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1385704/23751550/a7ef8504-04b0-11e7-8b51-9ceab7d83b20.gif)

Notice how `C` parameter and `.do` method are not correctly indented after format document depending on `.mergeMap` position.

It happens either in Typescript or Javascript syntax.

It seems a bug. People in gitter/vscode agreed, so I opened this issue.

data.title: Ignore folders/files in Problems view

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
The Problems View now lists all problems, even in 3rd party code like in node_modules, which is cluttering the actual problems of the opened project. You should be able to ignore certain folders/files while diagnosing/listing problems. This should be possible on a project basis, not as a VSCode setting. (thus in the .vscode/settings.json)

- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: Any

data.title: [json] improve error analysis on oneOf

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Adding an (unexpected) `env` attribute to a launch configuration of type `extensionHost` results in the following error: 

![2017-03-08_12-46-29](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1898161/23702884/896352b8-03fd-11e7-8913-580cf69480ed.png)

This error is misleading because the value `extensionHost` is flagged as wrong and not the unexpected use of `env`.

If the key value pair `"foo":"bar"` is removed from the `env` structure the error is flagged correctly:

![2017-03-08_12-52-03](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1898161/23703044/3a5f4f04-03fe-11e7-8e0f-ca8a2a6ea397.png)

It would help if the `type` attribute could be somehow excluded from the validation so that the validator does not try to assume that the `type` value is incorrect but all other attributes are correct.

The `type` attribute is basically a 'type defining' attribute that should be left alone.

data.title: As a user I would like to know what settings are being applied to current editor and the source of these settings

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Extracted from https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/21902

Currently there is not a good way to know what settings are being applied to the editor. You see this issue through language settings but this issue exists at other places too.

- Workspace settings
- Extensions like Editor config
- In memory configurations (toggle word wrap functionality)

I think we need a concept of Editor settings preview showing the settings applied to current editor and what are their sources? This will help user understanding about where settings are coming from and able to update/configure them.

I am open for ideas / feedback

data.title: Feature Request: Explorer should support custom order of folders/files
data.body:
It will be very useful to be able to reorder folders/files in explorer with drag&drop. In my project I am ordering my folders based on significance, so it is easier to find them, instead of searching for it based on name order.
View order could be stored in some dedicated project file view-order.json 
{name: 'folder-name', viewOrder: 1}. Hierarchy in file is not needed, as order is done per-node.
Folders/files which does not have view order entry should be ordered by name with lower priority than the once that have.

data.title: Test Tour: MEAN
data.body:
[Test Tours/Exploratory Testing](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/jj620911(v=vs.120).aspx#bkmk_tours). We will use a starter kit and use it for a 'GuideBook Tour'. The final goal would be to show a cool demo of how you can use VS Code to do MEAN.

You have discovered http://mean.io/ and want to use Code to get started.

- do you get the extension recommendations?
  - [angular language service extension](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=Angular.ng-template&showReviewDialog=true)
- set it up for development. 
  - setup debugging
  - setup tasks if applicable
  - setup linting
  - check Intellisense behaviour (do you need a jsconfig.json)
  - configure the exclusion for search and the explorer.
- start implement something fun
- are there additional JSON schemas that should be defined/used to simplify development
- check that all artifacts/file types have syntax coloring
- think of demo of some of the VS Code goodness

Link issues you discover to this issue.
Share findings in this issue.

data.title: No 32 bit linux repository
data.body:
Ok so I'm not sure if I'm using the wrong value or if VSCode doesn't have a 32 bit repository but when I try to add the repo manually I get an error saying VSCode doesn't support the arch, I have tried it with (i386,i686,32,x86,32bit) none of these seem to work. Please add a 32 bit repo for people with coal powered PCs who want an easy and streamlined update procedure. BTW thanks for the great app VSCode is awesome!

- VSCode Version:Latest
- OS Version:Xubuntu 16.04

Steps to Reproduce:
Enter into terminal ->
`kk@kk-lpt:~$ sudo sh -c 'echo "deb **[arch=i386]** http://packages.microsoft.com/repos/vscode stable main" > /etc/apt/sources.list.d/vscode.list'

kk@kk-lpt:~$ sudo apt-get update
Hit:1 http://archive.ubuntu.com/ubuntu xenial InRelease
Hit:2 http://packages.microsoft.com/repos/vscode stable InRelease                             
Hit:3 http://download.mono-project.com/repo/debian wheezy InRelease                           
Hit:4 http://archive.ubuntu.com/ubuntu xenial-updates InRelease
Hit:5 http://archive.ubuntu.com/ubuntu xenial-backports InRelease
Hit:6 http://archive.ubuntu.com/ubuntu xenial-security InRelease
Reading package lists... Done                     
**N: Skipping acquire of configured file 'main/binary-i386/Packages' as repository 'http://packages.microsoft.com/repos/vscode stable InRelease' doesn't support architecture 'i386**'`

data.title: Allow extensions to determine if a position is within a fold.

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
This is currently the most demanded features of VSCodeVim: https://github.com/VSCodeVim/Vim/issues/1004

The main problem with Folds and Vim is that some motions will skip right over folded areas (like moving up/down). We need to know if we are in a folded area so we can iterate these motions until we are out of the fold.

An API like `vscode.window.activeTextEditor.getAllFoldedRegions(): vscode.Range[]` would be ideal.

An API like `vscode.window.activeTextEditor.isPositionInFold(position: vscode.Position): boolean` would also be great.

data.title: Integrate Vorlon Desktop into vscode

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Feature request: [Vorlon.js](http://www.vorlonjs.io/) is awesome and since it's a [Mircosoft open source](https://github.com/MicrosoftDX/Vorlonjs/) project and the Vorlon Desktop version is based on Electron I think it should be integrated as an additional debugging panel in vscode.

Also, Vorlon is not as well known as it should be and the current distribution of vscode would increase its adoption by people that aren't aware of it yet.
